ygData.subject: Re: Phased Searching Writeup
ygData.msgSnippet: ... below... ... and ... are ... publication ... published? ... peer ... point for ... CV :) ... I agree with you here.  Especially if your work forms a useful

Subject: Re: Phased Searching Writeup
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Hi Ken,
> 
> Thanks for  response on the phased search write-up. Responses 
below...
> 
> Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> 
> >Here are some comments on your writeup.  I think it's great work 
and 
> >very helpful.  It seems from your preliminary results that phased 
> >search can significantly outperform complexification alone, so we 
> >might now be able to solve even harder problems.  For that reason 
> >alone, this is probably publication-worthy work, although there 
are 
> >a few things that should be addressed, or at least I'm curious 
about:
> >  
> >
> The first question here is,  if I were to make the write-up 
publication 
> worthy what avenues are open with regards to getting work 
published? 
> Placing the work on the internet works well up to a point, but a 
peer 
> reviewed paper has more credability and can be used as a base 
point for 
> further research by others, plus it is something to put in the ole 
CV :)
> 

I agree with you here.  Especially if your work forms a useful basis 
for further research, which seems possible, it would be helpful to 
have a publication to refer to when using phased searching.  

I think the best option for something like this is a conference 
paper.  Probably GECCO-2005 would be the best, which has a 
submission deadline in January, I believe.  Usually brand new 
research shows up at a conference before it goes to a journal in 
expanded form.  I think your work could get into GECCO, but you'd 
have to address the points below.

> >-Why is the phased search so much faster?  It seems to be 5 or 10 
> >times faster based on what you say, but that seems more dramatic 
> >than I would expect.  I guess it's because this task is all about 
> >network activation and has no "domain simulation" involved.  
> >
> Yeh, because the evaluation code is so simple and fast, something 
like 
> 90% (at a guess) of the execution time is spent in the actual NEAT 
> process of generating offspring, comparing genomes and decoding 
genomes 
> into working networks. Therefore if you reduce the size of the 
genomes 
> within the population then you can expect a dramatic speed up. 
There is 
> also a scaling issue in SharpNEAT right now that means that it 
slows 
> down a lot more than it should as the genome size increases. 
There's a 
> simple fix but I've not had time to work on SharpNEAT lately.
> 
> >That 
> >won't be the case in other domains, and therefore the speedup 
aspect 
> >of this might be misleading.  Therefore, it would be helpful to 
see 
> >comparison graphs with generations on the x axis instead of 
time.  
> >Usually people in machine learning are interested in # 
evaluations 
> >to get a soltuion rather than CPU time since ultimately that's 
the 
> >main factor in computational complexity.  Time alone doesn't give 
> >that information but generations does.
> >  
> >
> yes I can see the value in showing generation based graphs, with 
the 
> time based graphs the percieved benefit may just be from 
performing more 
> generations in a given amount of time - the none phased search 
runs may 
> have achieved the same result if allowed to run to the same # of 
> generations. I still like the time based graphs though because 
> ultimately we need to know if we can find solutions within 
realistic 
> time frames. It's not much use devising a technqiue that can solve 
> problem X within 1,000 years :)
> 

Sure that's true, but in the machine learning community it's very 
unusual to ignore # evaluations, so I don't think you could publish 
results with time-based graphs.  The best thing to do is show 
results in terms of # evals or # generations on the x axis, and 
separately mention the time differences.  

The main problem with using time in this case is it is so 
application dependent....it seems that in most applications the 
advantage would even out since most time is spent in domain 
simulation and not network activation.

> >-If you ran the complexifying or blended runs for the same number 
of 
> >generations as the phased runs would they catch up?  That's 
another 
> >reason it would be good to see a comparison by generations rather 
> >than time.  If they can't catch up in the same # of generations, 
> >that is a very strong result!
> >  
> >
> Yes I agree that this would be an interesting experiment to run.
> 
> >-To really validate this approach, we need a task that cannot be 
> >solved without hidden nodes.  So probably another experiment in a 
> >new domain would be a good idea.
> >  
> >
> I'm intending to do some phased search experiments with Tic-Tac-
Toe, and 
> probably function regression. The later hopefully leading on to 
some 
> form of financial data prediction experiment(s).
> 

Well before you jump into TTT, make sure it really does require some 
hidden nodes to do well?  Derek and Philip probably can speak to the 
complexity necessary in TTT from their own experiments.

> >-The # hidden nodes in a soltuion is interesting in its own 
right.  
> >For example, what is actually happening to keep complexity 
steady: 
> >Are connections being added then taken away back and forth over 
and 
> >over, or are several hidden layers being built at the same time 
as 
> >some inputs are being pruned?  A graph of # nodes per solution 
would 
> >give some insight.
> >  
> >
> The search is mainly one of finding connections. Although hidden 
nodes 
> do accumulate during the complexification phase they almost always 
are 
> completely removed by the end of a prune phase. Some  'common 
feature' 
> nodes exist by way of connections from output nodes to other 
output nodes.
> 

I see, that definitely suggests another domain is necessary to know 
how well phased searching really works since it is unlikely that 
hidden nodes can always spare to be pruned in most domains.

> 
> >-It would be interesting to see a picture of a solution network.  
It 
> >would help address the above point and also it's just fun to 
see :)
> >  
> >
> Yeh the problem here is that the networks from complexifying and 
blended 
> runs are really complex, whereas the ones that have been pruned 
have no 
> hidden node and frankly look a bit boring :)  One idea is to runt 
eh 
> networks from a complexifying run through a prune phase to prune 
away 
> redundant structure. My guess is that they will be utilising some 
hidden 
> nodes, possibly a lot, whereas the pruning phase nets normally 
don't 
> have any.
> 

Yes, that's interesting.  I think we'll know a lot if phased 
searching is applied to another domain.

Anyway, it's a great start and if you are seriously interested in 
publication, you may want to email me to discuss what you need to do 
in more detail.  

ken
